datafield.subfield: University of Michigan admissions lawsuits website,

The website series forms part of the collection of materials pertaining to two lawsuits filed in 1997 (Grantz, et al. v. Bollinger; and Grutter, et al. v. Bollinger) alleging that the University of Michigan's admissions practices discriminated against non-minority applicants.
The lawsuits made the university a focal point in the national debate over the value and legality of affirmative action in higher education.

University President Lee Bollinger and other members of the university community conducted a highly visible national media campaign to explain and elicit support for the university's admissions policies and the values upon which they were based, the lawsuits also stimulated intense discussion on the University of Michigan campus over issues of diversity, fairness and equal opportunity.
The website was one of the main communication devices the university used to disseminate information about the lawsuits to university faculty, students, and staff.

The Admissions Lawsuit website is a snapshot of the content and presentation of the website as of February 25, 2002. The website series contains statements of support from university leaders and court documents. The court documents include court transcripts, expert witness reports, memoranda, and defendant briefs.
